metadata.title: "Syed Muhammad Jaunpuri and the Mahdavi Movement:  A Historical, Religious, and Intellectual Analysis"
metadata.description:
Syed Muhammad Jaunpuri (Born 842 AH / 1443 CE – Died 910 AH / 1505 CE) was born in the city of Jaunpur, India. After completing his early education, he excelled in religious sciences and became a disciple of Sheikh Daniyal Chishti. Later, through his claims of spiritual visions and divine inspirations, he came to believe that he was the Promised Mahdi. He declared himself as such in Makkah and began preaching his message across India and Afghanistan.

His followers came to be known as the Mahdaviya. This movement spread its influence in Ahmadnagar, Gujarat, Deccan, and Sindh. Initially, some rulers—such as Ahmad Nizam Shah Bahri—supported him, but later, due to the protest of scholars and the sermon of Maulana Shah Tahir of Turkistan, Burhan Nizam Shah expelled the Mahdavis from his kingdom.

The paper elaborates on the beliefs of the Mahdaviya sect, according to which:

Syed Muhammad Jaunpuri considered himself superior to all prophets (except Prophet Muhammad

His followers regarded all prophets, saints, and even the Companions of the Prophet  as inferior to him.

They believed that some commandments of the Shariah of Muhammad  had been abrogated by the “Shariah of Jaunpuri.”

Books such as Shawahid al-Wilayah and Panj Fazail equated his sayings with divine revelation.

In conclusion, the author notes that the Mahdavi movement was strongly opposed by the Islamic rulers of Gujarat, Deccan, and Sindh, and that its founder eventually died in exile in Ferah (Afghanistan).

This paper explores one major aspect of the figure known as the “Indian Mahdi,” while other researchers argue that there exists another perspective on his personality, which is discussed in a separate article.
keywords: Jaunpuri, Mahdavi, Movement, Claim of Mahdihood, Ahmadnagar,

metadata.title: Short-term prediction of consumption and production of energy
metadata.description: The transformation of the electricity sector and the rapid penetration of photovoltaic power plants (PVPPs) are increasing the demand for accurate short-term predictions of PVPP consumption and production. Most studies work with large amounts of data and a fairly rich training set. In real-world cases, however, more challenging scenarios occur, where the available data is smaller in scope, as in our case, a 21-day window with a daily horizon and 15-minute resolution. Even in this case, however, it is desirable to have a suitable prediction method for implementing the necessary components into the tools used. In this work, we compare five families of methods including linear models, LightGBM boosting trees, decomposition Prophet, generalized recurrent neural networks and their variants such as Time GRNN and GRNN Boost, and MLP/ANN. We develop a specific framework for thoroughly testing these tools, including their evaluation using appropriate statistical tests and thorough analysis of prediction failures. LightGBM shows the most robust performance across days, while Time GRNN and GRNN Boost are practically suitable alternatives, especially for PV production, thanks to a reasonable compromise between median error, variability, and time stability. For the more difficult prediction of consumption, LightGBM also outperforms other approaches. Surprisingly, a sufficiently well-set linear model provides an acceptable alternative, despite its decreased temporal stability. The paper discusses both the quantitative sensitivity as well as specific limitations of individual methods.

metadata.title: Family Support Obligations From A Hadith Perspective
metadata.description: This research aims to comprehensively discuss the issue of family support obligations from the perspective of the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad. This research is library research. The data collection technique used is documentation. The documentation technique was chosen because this study examines hadiths of the Prophet found in several hadith books. The analysis technique used is descriptive qualitative. An important finding in this research is that living is an obligation that must be carried out by the husband as head of the household. Fulfilling the obligation to provide support to the family is considered alms. Thus, if a husband works sincerely to meet the needs of his family, then the husband is like giving alms. The husband's obligation to provide for his wife's needs according to Islamic law is to fulfill household needs in terms of clothing, food and shelter according to the husband's capabilities. Islam does not provide definite standards regarding the limits and amount of maintenance that is the husband's obligation.

metadata.title: Hassân bin Sâbit'in Cahiliye Dönemi ve İslâmî Döneme Ait Seçilmiş Methiye Örneklerinden Hareketle Ele Aldığı Konuların Mukayesesi
metadata.description: Arabic literature, deeply rooted in oral tradition, has experienced substantial shifts across historical periods, with one of the most transformative moments being the emergence of Islam in the 7th century. During the pre-Islamic era, known as the jāhiliyya (age of ignorance), poetry was central to Arab social and cultural life. It was not only a literary form but also a social instrument that reflected and reinforced the values of tribal society. Poets acted as spokespersons, historians, and moral guides within their communities. Poetry served to preserve the memory of tribal achievements, honor ancestors, and promote virtues such as courage, generosity, loyalty, and pride. Common themes in this period included warfare, tribal rivalry, honor, nature, love, and personal or communal glory. With the advent of Islam, profound changes occurred in the religious, moral, and intellectual life of the Arabian Peninsula. These changes also transformed the literary domain. Poets who lived through this transitional period faced the challenge of reorienting their art in accordance with the new Islamic worldview. The content and function of poetry were reshaped to reflect spiritual and ethical concerns aligned with Islamic values. Poetry now had to serve a greater religious purpose—defending Islam, praising the Prophet Muhammad, and promoting unity among believers. One of the most prominent poets who lived during this crucial transformation was Ḥassān ibn Thābit, a native of Medina. Ḥassān ibn Thābit initially rose to fame during the jāhiliyya period through his eloquent panegyrics (madīh) composed in praise of his tribe and its leaders. His poetry served traditional tribal functions: glorifying lineage, celebrating valor, and reinforcing tribal identity. However, after embracing Islam, Ḥassān shifted his poetic focus dramatically. Encouraged by the Prophet Muhammad himself, he employed his poetic skills in defense of Islam, composing verses that praised the Prophet, supported the Muslim cause, and refuted attacks from opponents. As a result, he became famously known as “the Poet of the Prophet.” His poetry serves as a valuable source for examining the transition from tribal to religious themes in Arabic literature. This study undertakes a comparative analysis of selected panegyric poems by Ḥassān ibn Thābit from both the pre-Islamic and Islamic periods. While many scholars have focused on his Islamic-era poetry, especially his eulogies for the Prophet and his satirical poetry targeting adversaries of Islam, fewer studies have compared the content and thematic orientation of his panegyrics across both periods. By examining selected examples from each era, this research explores the thematic evolution and shifts in purpose and tone in Ḥassān’s poetic work. In the pre-Islamic period, his poetry emphasized tribal ideals—such as lineage, physical strength, bravery in battle, and the honor of one’s clan. These poems aimed to solidify tribal cohesion and assert superiority in intertribal rivalries. The language was ornate, formal, and filled with metaphors and traditional imagery that appealed to the values of that time. In contrast, his Islamic-era panegyrics illustrate a transformation in both subject matter and intention. The focus of praise shifted from tribal leaders to religious figures, most notably the Prophet Muhammad. Themes such as piety, divine guidance, justice, patience, and spiritual strength began to dominate. The aim of poetry was no longer just to glorify a tribe, but to convey a universal religious message, defend the Prophet, and inspire moral behavior among the Muslim community. Nonetheless, Ḥassān retained many classical poetic features—such as traditional meter, rhyme schemes, and rhetorical techniques—blending old forms with new meanings. This continuity demonstrates how Arabic poetry adapted to serve the emerging Islamic identity while preserving its literary heritage. Through a close analysis of these panegyrics, this study highlights how Ḥassān ibn Thābit’s work reflects the broader cultural and ideological transformation that occurred with the rise of Islam. His poetry represents a rare literary bridge between two distinct eras, capturing both the continuity and the change in Arabic poetic tradition. The comparative approach provides insight into how literary expression responded to and shaped the evolving values of Arab-Islamic society.

metadata.title: Advancing precision in air quality forecasting through machine learning integration
metadata.description: In an era where environmental concerns are escalating, air quality forecasting emerges. Forecasting is a crucial tool for addressing the adverse impacts of pollution on public health and ecosystems. In urban centers like Bandar Lampung, economic activities intensify pollution levels. This condition leveraging advanced machine learning forecasting methods can significantly mitigate these effects. This study evaluates the precision of long short-term memory (LSTM) and Prophet methods in predicting air quality. This study utilizes data from January 12, 2022 to November 9, 2023. The results reveal a distinct advantage of the LSTM method over the Prophet. The LSTM method showcases superior accuracy across all evaluation metrics. Specifically, the LSTM method achieved an average root mean squared error (RMSE) of 5.38, mean absolute error (MAE) of 3.94, and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of 0.07. In contrast, the Prophet method recorded higher error rates, with an average RMSE of 18.48, MAE of 15.61, and MAPE of 0.25. These numbers underscore the LSTM method's robustness and reliability in forecasting air quality. The result highlights its potential as a pivotal resource for environmental monitoring and policymaking to safeguard public health and promote sustainable urban development.

metadata.title: JAFAR JABBARLI AS A PROPHET OF WOMEN'S FREEDOM AND DEFENDER OF WOMEN'S RIGHTS
metadata.description:
Jafar Jabbarli (1899–1934), one of the prominent representatives of 20th century Azerbaijani literature, is an artist who left a rich legacy in the fields of dramaturgy, poetry and journalism. The ideas of national freedom, social equality, enlightenment and humanism are leading in his work. The theme of women occupies a special place in Jabbarli's literary activity. He presents women not only within the family, but also as active participants in the development of society.

Jafar Jabbarli's female images are of great importance in Azerbaijani literature as an artistic expression of the idea of women's freedom. Through his heroes, the role of women in society was re-evaluated, ideals such as literacy, enlightenment, freedom and equality were brought to the fore. The images of Sevil and Almaz are not only artistic images, but also symbols of the historical development of Azerbaijani women.

The purpose of writing the article is to analyze Jafar Jabbarli's female images from an artistic-aesthetic, psychological and social perspective, and to determine their significance in Azerbaijani literature.

To achieve this goal, the following tasks are defined:

  • To study the state of the women's issue in the socio-political conditions of the period in which Jabbarli lived;
  • To analyze the principles of creating female images in the writer's dramatic works;
  • To reveal the artistic expression of women's freedom and enlightenment ideas in the works of "Sevil" and "Almaz";
  • To determine the socio-psychological functions of female images in other works;
  • To evaluate the symbolic role of Jabbarli's women in the history of the development of Azerbaijani women, etc.

During the research, literary-historical, comparative analysis, textual studies and systematic approach methods were used.
keywords: Jafar Jabbarli, women's freedom, women's rights, abolition of illiteracy, women's involvement in education, enlightenment, freedom, equality, etc.

metadata.title: Why Pigs Are Forbidden (Haram) in Islam- Scientific and Health Consideration.
metadata.description:
Why Pigs Are Forbidden (Haram) in Islam- Scientific and Health Consideration.

Abstract
This article examines the Islamic prohibition on pigs (swine/pork) from multiple angles: Qurʾanic texts, Prophetic traditions (Ḥadīth), jurisprudential consensus, theological rationale, and scientific/health arguments. It analyses how Islamic scholars have understood the prohibition, how it functions in legal theory (fiqh), and what empirical evidence has been cited historically and in modern times. The aim is to provide a balanced, well-referenced view of why pigs are considered haram in Islam.

Table of Contents

  1. Introduction
  2. Qurʾānic Evidence
  3. Ḥadīth and Early Islamic Commentary
  4. Jurisprudence (Fiqh) and Theological Interpretations
  5. Scientific, Health, and Environmental Considerations
  6. Counter-views & Critiques
  7. Discussion & Synthesis
  8. Conclusion

1. Introduction

Islamic dietary law (ṭaʿām) is one of the important components of the Shariah (Islamic law), governing what is halāl (permissible) and harām (forbidden). Among the forbidden foods, one of the most commonly discussed is pork (the flesh of pigs, pig by-products). This prohibition is shared with other Abrahamic faiths (Judaism, certain Christian traditions), but Islam articulates its own legal, moral, and spiritual rationale.

In this paper, “pigs” will refer to the animal sus (pig / swine) and “pork” to its flesh, and more broadly pig products. The article will address textual sources, scholarly interpretations, and scientific data, while also noting where empirical claims are strong, weak, or contested.

2. Qurʾānic Evidence

The prohibition of pork is clearly stated in several verses of the Qurʾān. Some of the main ones:

Surah (Chapter)

Ayah (Verse)

English Translation / Key Phrases

Notes

Al-Baqarah 2:173

“…and the flesh of swine…”

“He has forbidden you only the Maytah (dead animals), and blood, and the flesh of swine, and that which hath been invoked the name of other than Allah…” Islam-QA+2Muslim Life Guide+2

One of the first prohibitions listed among forbidden foods.

Al-Ma’idah 5:3

Similar language: “Prohibited to you are dead animals, blood, and the flesh of swine …” Muslim Life Guide+2Islam-QA+2

Reaffirmation; in the context of dietary law.

  

Al-Anʿām 6:145

“…for that surely is an impurity…” (regarding the flesh of swine) Islam-QA+2Muslim Life Guide+2

The term used is rijs (often translated impurity / abhorrent).

  

These verses present the prohibition as a divine command, without in the Qurʾān itself giving an explicit detailed reason (e.g. moral, health) for the prohibition beyond the term rijs (“impure” or “abominable”). Islamic scholarship has debated what rijs precisely implies. Islam-QA+2The Environmental Literacy Council+2

3. Ḥadīth and Early Islamic Commentary

The Qurʾān provides the command, and Ḥadīth literature (sayings or practices of the Prophet Muḥammad ﷺ) reinforce or clarify aspects of the law, and early exegesis (tafsīr) provides the interpretative framework.

Some relevant points:

  • The term rijs is used in the Quran and understood by the Prophet’s companions and later tafsirs as denoting ritual impurity, something to avoid. Early commentators (mufassirūn) such as Ibn Kathīr, Al-Tabarī, and others treat pigs as impure in body, and their flesh as forbidden.
  • There are narrations and legal decisions forbidding not only eating pig flesh but also dealing with pigs in certain capacities (trading, etc.) in classical fiqh. For example, a fatwa stating it is prohibited for a Muslim to rear pigs for business, even if the purpose is trade. About Islam

These traditions establish that the prohibition is comprehensive: the flesh, by-products, contact, etc., are considered in the jurisprudential domain.

4. Jurisprudence (Fiqh) and Theological Interpretations

4.1 Madhhab Consensus

Islamic law (Shariah) as interpreted through the major Sunni schools (Hanafi, Maliki, Shāfiʿi, Ḥanbali) and Shiʿa scholarship agree that the flesh of pig, its by-products, etc., are entirely forbidden (ḥarām). There is consensus (ijmāʿ) on this point. No mainstream school considers pork lawful. Even in cases of extreme necessity (e.g. possible starvation), some allowance is given under ḍarūra, but this does not become ‘lawful’ in normal circumstances. Tanazur+2mizanulmuslimin.com+2

4.2 Theological Rationale: impurity (Najāsah) and Divine Wisdom

  • Impurity (Najāsah / Rijs): The concept that pigs are najis (ritually impure) is often tied to the Qurʾānic term rijs. Many ulama (scholars) interpret that contact with pigs (their flesh, etc.) contaminates ritual purity, necessitating purification. The Environmental Literacy Council+1
  • Divine Command / Obedience: One of the primary theological principles is that Muslims obey what Allah commands without necessarily understanding all wisdoms. The Qurʾān emphasizes obedience: “We hear and obey” is a recurrent theme. The fact that Allah declares something forbidden is itself sufficient in Shariah even if reasons are partially unknown. Islam-QA+1
  • Wisdom (Ḥikmah): Scholars often invoke hikmah — that there is benefit or protection in the prohibitions, even if all benefits are not known by humans. This covers physical health, spiritual and moral well-being, community hygiene, etc. Some scholars caution, however, against overreliance on speculative health arguments as the primary reason, because these are contingent and may change, whereas divine law is fixed. The Environmental Literacy Council+1

4.3 Legal Implications of the Prohibition

  • Every part of pig (meat, fat, skin, etc.) is generally considered haram for consumption. The majority of scholars hold that no portion is permissible. Journal UIN SGD+1
  • The ruling extends to trade, using byproducts, etc. For example, a fatwa forbids a Muslim to rear pigs for business, even if not for consumption. About Islam
  • Necessity clause (ḍarūra): In Islam, extreme necessity can permit things otherwise forbidden, but the permissibility is highly restricted and temporary. The general view among scholars is that only life or death situations may allow consumption of haram items, including pig flesh. This however is by exception, not the rule. Islam-QA+1

5. Scientific, Health, and Environmental Considerations

Over centuries, Muslim scholars and writers have suggested empirical rationales for the prohibition. In modern times, some of these arguments have been re-examined in light of scientific research. Below are commonly cited arguments, their strengths, and criticism.

Alleged Reason

Summary of Claim

Supporting Evidence / Strengths

Criticisms / Weaknesses

Parasites and Diseases

Pork may carry parasites such as Trichinella spiralis, Taenia solium, etc., which can infect humans and cause serious illness (trichinosis, cysticercosis). The Environmental Literacy Council+3Journal UIN SGD+3IslamHouse.com+3

These are genuine risks, especially with undercooked or inadequately inspected meat; in some countries, such infections are documented.

  

Impurity & Unclean Habits

The pig’s feeding habits (consuming waste, unclean refuse) and wallowing in dirty environments make it more prone to contamination. This is used as a general hygiene argument. Muslim Life Guide+2Al-Islam.org+2

In many modern pig farms hygiene is tightly controlled; “filth” arguments may not strictly apply in all contexts. Also, many animals eat or are exposed to mud, filth, etc., yet are not condemned similarly.

  

High Fat / Health Risks

Pork is alleged to have high levels of saturated fats, cholesterol, risk of obesity, heart disease. Some argue pigs don’t sweat well so toxins accumulate. Muslim Life Guide+2Quran Mualim+2

Modern meat processing and breeding have changed fat content; many meats have fat and cholesterol risks, depends on diet, cooking, etc. Some claims (e.g. that pigs do not sweat) are disputed or simplified.

  

Disease Reservoirs (Zoonosis / Virus Mixing)

Pigs are sometimes mentioned as hosts for various zoonotic diseases, e.g. “mixing vessel” for influenza viruses. IslamHouse.com

True in some contexts, but risk varies; mitigation possible via veterinary controls; these risks are not unique to pigs.

  

Environmental / Practical Reasons

In some regions, raising pigs might be unsustainable, or pig meat may spoil more quickly in hot climates without refrigeration, etc. Historically, these may have been practical dangers.

Hard to generalize; with modern storage and farming, many of these limitations are less strong. Also, many historical dietary prohibitions may have mixed cultural, environmental, and religious elements.

  

While many of these arguments are plausible and have empirical support, scholars caution that they are supplementary. The primary basis remains textual and legal, not empirical. Empirical reasons can reinforce the divine wisdom but are not the source of the law in Shariah-theory.

6. Counter-views & Critiques

Any comprehensive discussion should acknowledge objections, debates, or alternative views.

  1. Objection: Scientific advances reduce risk
    Some argue that with proper farming, rigorous inspection, and modern cooking, the health risks of pork can be mitigated. If so, then some empirical arguments lose weight. Response: in Islamic jurisprudence, divine commands are not contingent on empirical circumstances. If Allah has forbidden something, even if the harm is reduced, the law remains.
  2. Objection: The reasons are speculative or post-hoc
    Some critics (both Muslim and non-Muslim) say that many “scientific reasons” are later rationalizations rather than reasons known in the early revelational period. Response: Islamic scholars largely accept that not all reasons are known; some wisdoms are known, some are not, and that is acceptable in Islamic theology. The concept of tafsīr bi’l-raʾy (interpretation via opinion) must be cautious.
  3. Cross-cultural dietary practices
    Many non-Muslim societies consume pork without evident widespread health crises. Critics argue this suggests that the prohibition might be more symbolic, moral, or identity-based than strictly hygiene or health. Islamic responses include that risk is relative; certain climate, storage, or sanitation practices in many Muslim societies historically made risk higher; also identity, spiritual cleanliness, obedience, and purity are essential components.

7. Discussion & Synthesis

Putting all of this together:

  • The prohibition of pigs in Islam is first and foremost textual: clear verses in the Qurʾān categorically forbid it. Theological and jurisprudential frameworks place divine command above empirical or contingent reasons.
  • Scholars accept that “impurity” (in the sense of ritual impurity) is embedded in the prohibition through terms such as rijs, najāsa. The concept is both physical (contact, cleanliness) and spiritual (symbolism, moral significance).
  • Empirical health arguments strengthen the perception of wisdom (ḥikmah) in the law. While modern science does not always validate every traditional claim (e.g. pigs not sweating, etc.), many risks (parasites, zoonoses, fat content) are established in many contexts.
  • The prohibition also serves broader functions: community identity, moral purification, discipline, boundaries, reminding believers of divine sovereignty.

Trichinella / tapeworm infections

Undercooked pork, poor veterinary oversight; common in some climates historically.

Meat inspection, freezing, cooking standards reduce risk.

High saturated fat / cholesterol

Pig fat viewed as unhealthy; fat content high in free-range pigs eating certain diets.

Selective breeding for leaner cuts; dietary regulation; nutritional labeling.

Zoonotic viruses / “mixing vessel” risk

Pigs exposed to wild animals; lack of biosecurity.

Biosecurity, veterinary controls, monitoring disease spread.

Hygienic unclean feeding

Pigs scavenging in waste; lack of sanitary housing.

Industrial farming can control diet and environment.

Figure 1. Legal-Textual vs. Empirical Foundations of the Prohibition

[Divine Command / Qurʾān & Ḥadīth]

             |

     --------------------

     |                  |

Spiritual / Ritual      Empirical (Health, Hygiene, Identity)

Purity, Obedience       (Risk, Health, Practicality)

(This is a conceptual diagram showing that textual basis is primary, empirical supports secondary.)

9. Conclusion

The prohibition of pigs/pork in Islam is firmly established in the Qurʾān and Ḥadīth, reinforced by the consensus of jurists. The primary basis is divine law and spiritual/legal framework, with “impurity” (najāsa/rijs), obedience, and wisdom being central themes.

Scientific and health arguments provide supporting reasons and help believers understand potential benefits of the rule, but they are not the foundational source of the prohibition. The wisdom in law is often that empirical risks are mitigated but the law retains its normative force.

Even where modern conditions reduce certain health risks, the religious significance—purity, identity, discipline, trust in divine wisdom—continues to maintain the prohibition in Islamic belief and law.

metadata.title: The Broken Mirror of Iran-Shahr: Myth, Trauma, and the Vertical Order of Iranian Politics
metadata.description: This working paper explores the longue durée of Iran-Shahr as a political-cosmological operating system. Drawing on Iranian history, mythology, psychoanalysis, and political theory, it argues that vertical hierarchy, paternal archetypes, and collective narcissism have repeatedly resurfaced under new ideological costumes, from Achaemenid farr to velāyat-e faqīh. The study integrates discourse analysis, myth studies, and critical theory to explain why modern revolutions and reforms in Iran often reinstall ancient logics rather than dismantle them.
